Newsvendor Problem under Dynamic Consumer Substitution¶

\[\DeclareMathOperator*{\argmax}{argmax}\]

(Integer-ordered variables, constrained.)

This example is adapted from the article Mahajan, S., & van Ryzin, G. (2001). Stocking Retail Assortments under Dynamic Consumer Substitution. Operations Research, 49(3), 334-351. 1

Problem Statement:

In the newsvendor problem under dynamic consumer substitution, the retailer sells \(n\) substitutable products \(j = 1, \ldots, n\), each with price \(p^j\) and cost \(c^j\) . The only decision variable is the vector of initial inventory levels \(x = (x_1, \ldots, x_n)\).

The newsvendor problem considered here differs from the classical newsvendor problem in that the demand is not given by a predetermined distribution, but depends on the initial inventory levels \(x\) as well. The customers \(t = 1, \ldots, T\) arrive in order and each can choose one product that is in-stock when he/she arrives, namely any element in \(S(x_t) = \{j : x^j_t > 0\} \cup \{0\}\) where \(0\) denotes the no-purchase option.

Each customer \(t\) assigns a utility \(U^j_t\) to option \(j = 0, \ldots, n\), and thus \(U_t = (U^0_t, U^1_t, \ldots, U^n_t)\) is his/her vector of utilities. Note that \(U^j_t\) is the utility of product \(j\) net of the price \(p^j\), and therefore could be negative. Since the no-purchase option \(0\) incurs neither utility nor cost, one can assume \(U^0_t = 0\). Customer \(t\) maximizes his/her utility by making the choice

\[d(x_t,U_t) = \argmax_{j\in S(x_t)} U^j_t\]
Let \(\omega = \{U_t : t = 1, \ldots, T\}\) follows the probability distribution \(P\). We consider a one-period inventory model and assume \(P(T < +\infty) = 1\).
The retailer knows the probability measure \(P\), and his/her objective is to choose \(x\) that maximizes total expected profit.

Recommended Parameter Settings:

Use the Multinomial Logit (MNL) model. \(U^0_t, U^1_t, \ldots, U^n_t\) are mutually independent random variables of the form

\[U^j_t = u^j + \epsilon^j_t\]

where \(uj\) is a constant and \(\epsilon^j_t\), \(j = 0, 1, \ldots, n\) are mutually independent Gumbel random variables with \(P(\epsilon^j_t \leq z) = \exp(-e^{-(z/\mu+\gamma)})\) (\(\gamma\) is Euler’s constant, \(\gamma \approx 0.5772\).)

Setting 1: \(n = 2, T = 5, u_j = 1, \mu = 1\).

Setting 2: \(n = 10, T = 30, u_j = 5 + j, \mu = 1\).

Starting Solutions: \(x = (2, 3)\) in Setting 1, \(x = (3, 3, \ldots, 3)\) in Setting 2.

Measurement of Time: Number of sample paths \(\omega\) simulated.

Optimal Solutions: Unknown.

Known Structure: Under the recommended parameter settings of Multinomial Logit model, the choice probabilities are given by

\[\begin{split}q^j(S) &= P(U^j_t = \text{max}\{U^i_t: i \in S\}) \\ &= \frac{v_j}{\sum_{i \in S}v^i + v^0},\end{split}\]

where

\[\begin{split}vj = \begin{cases} e^{u_j / \mu} & j \in S,\\ e^{u_0 / \mu} & j = 0. \end{cases}\end{split}\]

References

1

Mahajan, S., & van Ryzin, G. (2001). Stocking Retail Assortments under Dynamic Consumer Substitution. Operations Research, 49(3), 334-351.
